unnormalised: It all started last monsoon. Mumbai was drowning, literally. My chawl in Dadar got flooded up to the 2nd floor. Lost everything – my TV, my Amma’s saree collection, even my ID cards. That’s when I realized, life’s unpredictable.
normalised: My friend, Ramesh, an L-I-C agent, kept telling me to get insurance. "Arre, it’s a safety net, yaar! Think of your family," he'd say, sipping chai at the tapri near my office. I always shrugged it off. Who has money for all that?

unnormalised: My friend, Ramesh, an LIC agent, kept telling me to get insurance. "Arre, it’s a safety net, yaar! Think of your family," he'd say, sipping chai at the tapri near my office. I always shrugged it off. Who has money for all that?
normalised: But the flood changed everything. I started saving, cutting down on my daily vada pav. Visited Ramesh's office, a tiny room above a mithai shop in Matunga. He explained the various policies – term insurance, U-L-I-Ps, health insurance. All sounded confusing, like Bollywood movie plots with too many twists.

unnormalised: But the flood changed everything. I started saving, cutting down on my daily vada pav. Visited Ramesh's office, a tiny room above a mithai shop in Matunga. normalised: I was drawn to a term insurance plan. It felt the most straightforward. If something happened to me, at least my family, Amma and little Pooja, would get rupee one crore. That seemed like enough to secure their future, pay off debts, and Pooja could continue her schooling.

unnormalised: I was drawn to a term insurance plan. It felt the most straightforward. If something happened to me, at least my family, Amma and little Pooja, would get ₹1 crore. That seemed like enough to secure their future, pay off debts, and Pooja could continue her schooling.
normalised: The paperwork was a pain. Aadhaar card copies, P-A-N card details, medical checkups. It felt like applying for a government job. But Ramesh helped me through it. He even negotiated a better premium rate, said he pulled some strings with his branch manager, Mister Sharma. The total annual premium came to rupees twelve thousand, a bit of a stretch, but manageable.

normalised: Fast forward to now. Thankfully, nothing major has happened. Touchwood! But knowing I have that insurance policy gives me a sense of peace. I pay the premium on time, religiously, online through PhonePe. And I even convinced my neighbour, Abdul Bhai, an auto-rickshaw driver, to get insurance too.
